title: Antonio Filippini
text:
Antonio Filippini (born 3 July 1973) is an Italian <a href="Association%20football">football</a> coach and a former player who played mainly as a <a href="Midfielder%23Defensive%20midfielder">defensive midfielder</a>.
He played in several teams with his <a href="twin">twin</a> brother, <a href="Emanuele%20Filippini">Emanuele</a>, and spent most of his extensive career with <a href="Brescia%20Calcio">Brescia</a>, amassing <a href="Serie%20A">Serie A</a> totals of 303 games and 12 goals over the course of 11 seasons.
Football career.
Filippini was born in <a href="Brescia">Brescia</a>. Having emerged through hometown <a href="Brescia%20Calcio">Brescia Calcio</a>'s youth system he stayed there for eight professional seasons, after having started – on loan – with amateurs Ospitaletto, the first of many teams he shared with his sibling <a href="Emanuele%20Filippini">Emanuele</a>. The pair made their <a href="Serie%20A">Serie A</a> debut on 31 August 1997, in a 1–2 away loss against <a href="Inter%20Milan">Inter Milan</a>.
In January 2004, Filippini moved to the <a href="Serie%20B">Serie B</a> with <a href="U.S.%20Citt%C3%A0%20di%20Palermo">U.S. Città di Palermo</a>. He was crucial to the <a href="Sicily">Sicilians</a>' <a href="2003%E2%80%9304%20Serie%20B">promotion</a>, with 21 matches in only five months.
After a solid <a href="2004%E2%80%9305%20Serie%20A">campaign</a> with <a href="S.S.%20Lazio">S.S. Lazio</a> and a year with lowly <a href="Treviso%20F.B.C.%201993">Treviso F.B.C. 1993</a>, Filippini signed with <a href="A.S.%20Livorno%20Calcio">A.S. Livorno Calcio</a> on a <a href="Free%20transfer%20%28association%20football%29">free transfer</a> in 2006, being rejoined by Emanuele (also his teammate at Lazio and Treviso) the following year and helping the side return to the top flight in <a href="2008%E2%80%9309%20Serie%20B">his third season</a>, with 24 matches and one goal.
Filippini rejoined Brescia's for <a href="2010%E2%80%9311%20Serie%20A">2010–11</a>, after 18 years. Following the team's top level relegation, he retired in June 2011 at the age of 38.
Coaching career.
On 25 June 2012, it was announced that both brothers would join lower league club <a href="FeralpiSal%C3%B2">FeralpiSalò</a> as youth system coordinators.
He successively served as the head coach of <a href="A.C.%20Lumezzane">Lumezzane</a> in 2016, then managing <a href="Serie%20D">Serie D</a> club Trento from November 2017 to March 2018.
In November 2019, he was appointed assistant coach at <a href="A.S.%20Livorno%20Calcio">Livorno</a>. On 8 March 2020, with the club at the bottom of the Serie B league table, he was promoted to head coach, replacing <a href="Roberto%20Breda">Roberto Breda</a>. He was dismissed following Livorno's relegation to <a href="Serie%20C">Serie C</a> at the end of the 2019–20 season.
On 29 March 2021, he was hired by <a href="Serie%20C">Serie C</a> club <a href="Pro%20Sesto%202013">Pro Sesto</a>. He was sacked on 19 September 2021 following a negative start in the <a href="2021%E2%80%9322%20Serie%20C">2021–22 Serie C</a> campaign.
